Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Acellular Dermal Matrix in Implant-Based Breast Reconstruction

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned (1:1) to IBBR with or without ADM.

Participants.evidence: Women with breast cancer scheduled for mastectomy with immediate IBBR were recruited from four centres in Sweden and one in the UK.

Intervention.evidence: IBBR with acellular dermal matrix (ADM) improves health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and patient-reported cosmetic outcomes compared to conventional IBBR without ADM.

Objective.evidence: This multicentre open-label randomised controlled trial evaluated whether implant-based breast reconstruction (IBBR) with acellular dermal matrix (ADM) improves health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and patient-reported cosmetic outcomes compared to conventional IBBR without ADM.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the number of reoperations within 6 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed until baseline questionnaires were completed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From April 2014 to May 2017, 135 women were randomised: 65 to ADM and 70 to control.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 64 in the ADM group and 65 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Cosmetic outcomes showed small differences favoring ADM in two subscales: cosmetic outcome (mean difference 8.66, 95% CI 0.46 to 16.86; p = 0.041) and problems finding a well-fitting bra (mean difference -13.21, 95% CI -25.54 to -0.89; p = 0.038).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events requiring reoperation were more frequent in the ADM group.
